profileText: A Senator from New Jersey; born in Philadelphia, Pa., November 20, 1873; moved with his parents to Pleasantville, N.J., in 1877; attended the public schools; employed in a printing office in Atlantic City, N.J., 1890-1894; newspaper owner and publisher; journal clerk of the State senate 1897-1899; during the Spanish-American War served as a second lieutenant; secretary of the State senate 1901-1904; member, State house of assembly 1910; member, State senate 1911-1916, serving as president in 1915; Governor of New Jersey 1917-1919, when he resigned, having been elected United States Senator; elected as a Republican to the United States Senate in 1918; reelected in 1924 and served from March 4, 1919, until his resignation on November 21, 1929, to accept a diplomatic post; chairman, Committee on Coast and Insular Survey (Sixty-sixth Congress), Committee on Interoceanic Canals (Sixty-seventh through Seventy-first Congresses), Committee on Post Office and Post Roads (Sixty-eighth Congress); appointed Ambassador to France by President Herbert Hoover 1929-1933; again Governor of New Jersey 1944-1947; died in New York City, October 29, 1956; interment in Northwood Cemetery, Downingtown, Pa.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Edge, Walter E. A Jerseyman's Journal: Fifty Years of American Business and Politics. 1948. Reprint. New York: Johnson Reprint Corp., 1972.

Levering, Ralph B. "Partisanship, Ideology, and Attitudes toward Woodrow Wilson: New Jersey's Republican Senators and the League of Nations Controversy, 1918-1920.'' New Jersey History 109 (Fall/Winter 1991): 1-13.

researchRecord.name: April 11, 1918; December 17, 1918. 2 letters. To Frank H. Stewart concerning the care of historical documents.

recordLocation.name: Archives and Special Collections, Campbell Library

researchRecord.name: 1916-1956. 8 feet. Correspondence, personal files, and scrapbooks chiefly concerning his ambassadorship to France, 1929-1933.
Correspondence in Mary Philbrook papers, 1899-1958; Joseph P. Bradley papers, 1836-1937; and Federal Writers' Project, 1890-1953.

1920-1968 (bulk 1930-1956). 22.95 cubic feet. Correspondence, appointment books, clippings, memorabilia; documents and financial files; books; writings, galley proofs; photographs, certificates; and scrapbooks. Includes typescripts and galley proofs for his memoirs, A Jerseyman's Journal: Fifty Years of American Business and Politics (1948). Finding aid.
Correspondence in J. Theodore Marriner papers, 1918-1937.
